H0.text: Oil, air, and rock are examples of matter that can take the shape of a container.

H1.text: Water, air, and milk are examples of matter that can take the shape of a container.

H2.text: The list “sand, ice, and wood” includes only examples of matter that can take the shape of a container.

H3.text: Nail, stick, and paper are examples of matter that can take the shape of a container.

A4.text: Liquid is a state of matter with a definite volume but no fixed shape. When resting in a container, liquids typically adapt to the shape of the container.

A5.text: Liquid crystals, for example, flow like liquids but exhibit long-range orientational alignment of their molecules.
